docs.title: Trigger Actions Explorer
docs.text: A Lightning Web Component application for managing trigger actions and their execution order.

docs.title: Key Features
docs.text:
• Visual Trigger Management: Create and edit trigger actions through an intuitive interface
  • Order Management: Reorder actions using arrows or manual decimal entry
  • Formula Validation: Real-time validation of Entry Criteria formulas
  • Change Data Platform Support: Special handling for Change Data Capture events
  • State Persistence: Maintains selections across deployments

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
1. Install the application using the unlocked package
  2. Create your first Trigger Setting
  3. Add Trigger Actions to your setting
  4. Organize the execution order as needed

docs.title: Documentation Structure
docs.text:
• Installation - How to install and configure the application
  • Creating Trigger Settings - Setting up SObject trigger configurations
  • Creating Trigger Actions - Building and managing trigger actions
  • Sorting Trigger Actions - Managing execution order

docs.title: Creating Trigger Actions
docs.text: Trigger Actions define the specific logic that executes when triggers fire on your configured objects. This guide covers creating, editing, and managing trigger actions within the Trigger Actions Explorer.

docs.title: What are Trigger Actions?
docs.text:
Trigger Actions are custom metadata records that define:

  • Action Type: Apex class or Flow execution
  • Execution Context: Before/After Insert/Update/Delete/Undelete
  • Entry Criteria: Formula-based conditions for execution
  • Order: Execution sequence within the same context
  • Permissions: Required and bypass permissions
  • Description: Documentation of the action's purpose

docs.title: Step 1: Access the Creation Interface
docs.text:
1. Select your Trigger Setting from the SObject dropdown
  2. Choose the appropriate Context (Before/After)
  3. Select the Timing (Insert/Update/Delete/Undelete)
  4. Click Add Action in the desired section (Before Actions or After Actions)

docs.title: Step 2: Choose Action Type
docs.text: The modal will present different action types based on your object selection:

docs.title: Apex Actions
docs.text:
• Use case: Custom business logic, complex processing
  • Class Name: Enter the Apex class that contains your logic
  • Example: AccountValidationHandler, ContactDuplicateCheck

docs.title: Flow Actions
docs.text:
• Use case: Declarative automation, simple business rules
  • Flow Name: Enter the Flow API name
  • Recursion Control: Allow or prevent recursive execution

docs.title: Flow (CDP) Actions
docs.text:
• Use case: Change Data Platform events (ChangeEvent objects only)
  • Availability: Only shown for objects ending with ChangeEvent
  • Flow Name: Enter the Flow API name for CDP processing

docs.title: Developer Name
docs.text:
• Auto-generated: Based on your selections and context
  • Format: {Actioniname}_{ContextName}
  • Example: AccountSetName_BI, AccountSetRiskClass_BU
  • Note: Cannot be changed after creation

docs.title: Label
docs.text:
• Required: User-friendly name for the action
  • Examples: "Validate Account Data", "Update Contact Status", "Create Opportunity Tasks"
  • Note: This appears in the action card display

docs.title: Description
docs.text:
• Required: Detailed explanation of what the action does
  • Examples: "Validates account data before saving", "Updates contact status based on email domain"
  • Note: Helps other developers understand the action's purpose

docs.title: Order
docs.text:
• Purpose: Determines execution sequence within the same context
  • Format: Decimal numbers (e.g., 1.0, 1.5, 2.0)
  • Note: Lower numbers execute first, can be ordered inside of the app

docs.title: Entry Criteria
docs.text:
• Purpose: Formula-based conditions for when the action should execute
  • Format: Salesforce formula syntax
  • Examples:
  • NOT(ISBLANK(record.Email))
  • AND(record.Type = "Customer", ISPICKVAL(record.Status,"Active"))
  • record.Amount > 10000
  • Note: Only executes when formula evaluates to true

docs.title: Required Permission
docs.text:
• Optional: Permission required to execute this action
  • Examples: CustomPermission, SystemPermission
  • Note: Users without this permission will skip this action

docs.title: Bypass Permission
docs.text:
• Optional: Permission that allows bypassing this specific action
  • Examples: BypassValidation, AdminOverride
  • Note: Users with this permission will skip this action

docs.title: Bypass Execution
docs.text:
• Checkbox: When checked, disables this specific action
  • Use case: Temporarily disable an action without deleting it
  • Note: Useful for troubleshooting or maintenance

docs.title: Description of What Means What in a Trigger Action Card
docs.text: Each trigger action is displayed as a card with the following content:

docs.title: Card Structure
docs.text:
• Order: Execution order number
  • Header: Action Label, Action Type, Action Name (Class/Flow), and Entry Criteria indicator
  • Description: The detailed explanation you provided
  • Badge: Active/Bypassed status indicator

docs.title: Evaluate Entry Criteria Directly in the UI
docs.text: The Trigger Actions Explorer includes built-in formula validation to help you create accurate Entry Criteria.

docs.title: Accessing Formula Validation
docs.text:
1. Create or Edit a trigger action
  2. Enter your formula in the Entry Criteria field
  3. Click the Validate button (appears below the Text Area)

docs.title: Validation Process
docs.text:
The validation system:

  1. Checks syntax: Ensures your formula is syntactically correct
  2. Validates field references: Confirms referenced fields exist on the object
  3. Tests formula logic: Verifies the formula can be evaluated
  4. Returns results: Shows success or detailed error messages

docs.title: Success
docs.text:
• Green checkmark icon with "Valid!" message
  • Save button enabled: You can proceed with saving
  • Confidence: Your formula will work in production

docs.title: Error
docs.text:
• Red error icon with detailed error message
  • Save button disabled: Prevents saving invalid formulas
  • Error details: Specific information about what's wrong

docs.title: Editing Actions
docs.text:
1. Click the Edit button (pencil icon) on any action card
  2. Make your changes in the modal
  3. Validate Entry Criteria if modified
  4. Click Save to update the action

docs.title: Viewing Actions
docs.text:
1. Click the View button (eye icon) on any action card
  2. Review all details in read-only mode
  3. Close the modal when finished

docs.title: Deleting Actions
docs.text: This is currently not supported by the Apex Metadata API. To delete an action, click the Action Label (highlighted blue) to visit the Metadata Record and delete it from there.

docs.title: Naming Conventions
docs.text:
• Labels: Use descriptive, business-friendly names
  • Descriptions: Provide clear explanations of purpose
  • Developer Names: Let the system auto-generate for consistency

docs.title: Entry Criteria Design
docs.text:
• Test thoroughly: Use the validation feature
  • Keep it simple: Avoid overly complex formulas
  • Document logic: Explain complex conditions in descriptions

docs.title: Permission Management
docs.text:
• Use sparingly: Only add permissions when necessary
  • Document requirements: Explain why permissions are needed
  • Test with different users: Verify permission behavior

docs.title: Order Management
docs.text:
• Plan execution order: Consider dependencies between actions
  • Use decimal ordering: Allows for easy insertion of new actions
  • Document dependencies: Note which actions depend on others

docs.title: "Formula validation failed"
docs.text:
• Check formula syntax
  • Verify field names are correct
  • Ensure object has the referenced fields

docs.title: "Action not executing"
docs.text:
• Check Entry Criteria formula
  • Verify action is not bypassed
  • Confirm execution order is correct

docs.title: Syntax Errors
docs.text:
• Missing parentheses: Check for balanced parentheses
  • Invalid operators: Use correct comparison operators
  • Field references: Ensure field names are exact

docs.title: Field Reference Errors
docs.text:
• Non-existent fields: Verify fields exist on the object
  • Incorrect field types: Check field data types
  • Permission issues: Ensure access to referenced fields

docs.title: Next Steps
docs.text:
After creating your trigger actions:

  1. Organize execution order using the sorting features
  2. Test your configurations thoroughly

docs.title: Creating SObject Trigger Settings
docs.text: SObject Trigger Settings are the starting point that defines whether an object is running in the Trigger Actions Framework. They enable trigger action management for specific Salesforce objects.

docs.title: What are Trigger Settings?
docs.text:
SObject Trigger Settings are custom metadata records that define:

  • Object Configuration: Which Salesforce object participates in the Trigger Actions Framework
  • Namespace Handling: Support for managed packages
  • TriggerRecord Class: Optional Apex class for custom Entry Criteria evaluation in Trigger Actions
  • Permissions: Required and bypass permissions for execution
  • Execution Control: Whether the trigger is active or bypassed

docs.title: Example Configuration
docs.text:
Object API Name: Account
Label: Account
TriggerRecord Class: AccountTriggerRecord

docs.title: Step 1: Access the Creation Interface
docs.text:
1. Open the Trigger Actions Explorer application
  2. Click the Add New SObject Trigger Setting button (plus icon) in the top-right corner
  3. The Trigger Setting Modal will open

docs.title: Object API Name
docs.text:
• Required field: Enter the API name of the Salesforce object
  • Examples: Account, Contact, Opportunity, CustomObject__c
  • Note: Use the exact API name as it appears in Salesforce

docs.title: Label
docs.text:
• Required field: A user-friendly name for the trigger setting
  • Examples: "Account Trigger", "Contact Management", "Opportunity Processing"
  • Note: This will be displayed in the Trigger Settings dropdown

docs.title: Object Namespace
docs.text:
• Optional field: For managed packages, enter the namespace
  • Examples: mypackage, sfdc, npsp
  • Note: Leave blank for unmanaged objects

docs.title: TriggerRecord Class Name
docs.text:
• Optional field: Apex class for custom Entry Criteria evaluation in Trigger Actions
  • Examples: AccountTriggerRecord, ContactTriggerRecord, OpportunityTriggerRecord
  • Note: Only required if you want to use custom Entry Criteria formulas in Trigger Actions

docs.title: Required Permission
docs.text:
• Optional field: Permission required to execute trigger actions
  • Examples: CustomPermission, SystemPermission
  • Note: Only users with this permission will have trigger actions executed

docs.title: Bypass Permission
docs.text:
• Optional field: Permission that allows bypassing trigger execution
  • Examples: BypassTriggers, AdminOverride
  • Use case: Users with this permission will skip trigger execution

docs.title: Bypass Execution
docs.text:
• Checkbox: When checked, disables all trigger actions for this object
  • Use case: Temporarily disable triggers without deleting configurations
  • Note: This is useful for maintenance or troubleshooting

docs.title: Step 5: Save the Setting
docs.text:
1. Click Save to create the Trigger Setting
  2. The modal will close and return to the main interface
  3. Your new setting will appear in the SObject dropdown

docs.title: Editing a Trigger Setting
docs.text:
1. Click the Edit SObject Trigger Setting button (pencil icon)
  2. Make your changes in the modal
  3. Click Save to update the setting

docs.title: Viewing Trigger Setting Details
docs.text:
1. Select the Trigger Setting from the dropdown
  2. The interface will show all associated trigger actions
  3. Use the context and timing dropdowns to filter actions

docs.title: Naming Conventions
docs.text:
• Labels: Use descriptive, business-friendly names
  • Object API Names: Use exact Salesforce API names
  • TriggerRecord Classes: Follow your org's naming conventions

docs.title: Permission Management
docs.text:
• Required Permissions: Use sparingly to avoid performance impact
  • Bypass Permissions: Grant only to administrators and support users
  • Documentation: Document permission requirements for future reference

docs.title: Object Selection
docs.text:
• Standard Objects: Account, Contact, Opportunity, Lead, etc.
  • Custom Objects: Any custom object in your org
  • Platform Events: Objects ending with ChangeEvent
  • Restored Objects: Objects with Restored context

docs.text: Copy the contents of the repo into your own repository and deploy in your own CI environment.

docs.title: Sorting Trigger Actions
docs.text: The Trigger Actions Explorer provides two modes for managing execution order:

docs.title: Ordering Mode (Default)
docs.text:
• Visual reordering using up/down arrows
  • Automatic integer numbering (1, 2, 3, etc.)
  • Overwrites existing order values - may be problematic in package-based approaches

docs.title: Manual Mode
docs.text:
• Direct number entry with up to 4 decimal places
  • Preserves your entered values (1.5, 2.25, 3.0)
  • Real-time reordering as you enter values

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
1. Click "Edit Order" in any action section
  2. Toggle between modes using the "Manual" switch
  3. Make your changes (arrows or number entry)
  4. Click "Save Order" and confirm

docs.title: Important Note
docs.text: Ordering Mode overwrites existing order values with sequential integers. This can cause issues in package-based deployments where order values are managed externally. Use Manual Mode to preserve specific order values.
